ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Great methods course, excellent workshop for giving and receiving feedback, good class for thinking about different ways of doing research.

I improved my ability to craft a compelling introduction, article draft and provide feedback on other students work. This course is a fantastic example of an effective research course in the history department.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Great workshop course, excellent assignments and group feedback. Helpful to have some weeks off for research and writing.

The workshop style is a fantastic model since it truly fulfills the goal a research course. It inspires a sense of comradery and cooperation and allows you to see how other students approach writing. Rather than assigning both working on the research paper and a lot of reading each week that student will likely not get to, Joanne makes the research and research paper the clear focus of the course. What an amazing chance to receive feedback on your writing from so many other students as well as a professor.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, great research course for your own work and thinking more deeply about Early National America and historical and research methods.

Yes definitelyit gives you a wonderful chance to learn how to write a historical article. The course breaks down various elements involved such as handling a variety of evidence, writing a prospectus, and writing an introduction and you receive feedback from other students as well as Joanne along the way.
